sites.title: Alcatraz Island
sites.summary: Former federal prison on an island in San Francisco Bay, known for housing notorious criminals.
sites.description_md:
# Alcatraz Island

Alcatraz Island served as a federal prison from 1934 to 1963, housing some of America's most notorious criminals including Al Capone. The island's isolation in the cold waters of San Francisco Bay made it an ideal maximum-security facility.

## Native American Occupation

From 1969 to 1971, the island was occupied by Native American activists, bringing attention to indigenous rights and federal treaty violations.

sites.title: Golden Gate Bridge
sites.address: Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco, CA 94129
sites.summary: Iconic suspension bridge connecting San Francisco to Marin County, completed in 1937.
sites.description_md:
# Golden Gate Bridge

Completed in 1937, the Golden Gate Bridge was the world's longest suspension bridge at the time of its construction. The bridge's distinctive International Orange color was chosen to enhance visibility in San Francisco's frequent fog.

citations.label: Golden Gate Bridge Highway & Transportation District

sites.title: Lombard Street
sites.summary: Famous winding street known as the 'most crooked street in the world' with eight hairpin turns.
sites.description_md:
# Lombard Street

The section of Lombard Street between Hyde and Leavenworth Streets features eight sharp hairpin turns designed in 1922 to reduce the hill's natural 27% grade, making it safer for vehicles to navigate.

sites.title: Chinatown
sites.address: Grant Ave & Bush St, San Francisco, CA 94108
sites.summary: Oldest Chinatown in North America and largest Chinese enclave outside of Asia.
sites.description_md:
# San Francisco Chinatown

Established in 1848, San Francisco's Chinatown is the oldest in North America and one of the largest Chinese enclaves outside of Asia. The neighborhood survived the 1906 earthquake and fire, rebuilding with distinctive architecture.

sites.title: Palace of Fine Arts
sites.summary: Monumental structure originally built for the 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition.
sites.description_md:
# Palace of Fine Arts

Designed by Bernard Maybeck for the 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition, the Palace of Fine Arts is the only structure from the exposition that remains today. The rotunda and colonnade reflect classical Greek and Roman architecture.

citations.label: Palace of Fine Arts Theatre
citations.publisher: Palace of Fine Arts Theatre Foundation

sites.title: Fisherman's Wharf
sites.summary: Historic waterfront area that evolved from a working fishing harbor to a major tourist destination.
sites.description_md:
# Fisherman's Wharf

Fisherman's Wharf developed in the early 1900s as a working fishing harbor. Italian immigrant fishermen established the area's fishing industry, and it gradually evolved into one of San Francisco's most popular tourist destinations.

sites.title: Coit Tower
sites.address: 1 Telegraph Hill Blvd, San Francisco, CA 94133
sites.summary: Art Deco tower on Telegraph Hill featuring Depression-era murals and panoramic city views.
sites.description_md:
# Coit Tower

Built in 1933 with funds bequeathed by Lillie Hitchcock Coit, this 210-foot Art Deco tower sits atop Telegraph Hill. The interior features murals painted by local artists as part of the Public Works of Art Project during the Great Depression.

sites.title: Cable Car Museum
sites.summary: Working powerhouse and museum showcasing San Francisco's historic cable car system.
sites.description_md:
# Cable Car Museum

Housed in the Washington-Mason powerhouse built in 1887, this museum displays the mechanical workings of San Francisco's cable car system. Visitors can see the massive wheels and cables that power the city's iconic cable cars.

sites.title: Mission Dolores
sites.summary: Oldest surviving structure in San Francisco, founded as part of the Spanish mission system.
sites.description_md:
# Mission San Francisco de AsÃ­s (Mission Dolores)

Founded in 1776, Mission Dolores is the oldest surviving structure in San Francisco. The adobe church, completed in 1791, represents the Spanish colonial period and the beginning of European settlement in the area.

sites.title: Haight-Ashbury
sites.address: Haight St & Ashbury St, San Francisco, CA 94117
sites.summary: Historic neighborhood that became the center of the 1960s counterculture and hippie movement.
sites.description_md:
# Haight-Ashbury

The intersection of Haight and Ashbury Streets became synonymous with the 1960s counterculture movement. The neighborhood attracted thousands of young people during the 'Summer of Love' in 1967, becoming the epicenter of hippie culture.
